ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Kanchan
Kanchan Strestha

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: For the first exposure to Policy Science it was a bit difficult to grasp in the beginning

Question 8.1. The course was poorly structured, and so were the classes. There was no correlation between the class content and the readings.2. The class was advertised as being a discussion intensive seminar; On the contrary, questions raised on readings and class content were skipped over, and never addressed.3. The instructor also displayed favoritism in the class. Regardless of final grades, this was not good for morale.4. The grading system was very ambiguous. There are no ongoing evaluations/ indicators for one's grades.5. Content-wise, the course was limited to the (un-critical) study of the policy sciences framework. While we dabbled other topics, we talked about them in a superficial manner, without any critical analyses.

10 - This is a truly excellent course and possibly one of the best I will take at the university.7 - Professor Clark is truly excellent, and not only was readily available for discussion with students, but also provided strong mentorship and excellent insight into applying theory and concepts learned in class to real problems.

This is a polarizing course, and a hard one to describe. Some people find it very helpful. Some have other opinions. I thought it provided an excellent way to get some purchase on complex problems, as well as a new way of thinking about policy.

This class provided a good introduction to the policy sciences framework and helped me to understand a new way to approach and understand problems. However, during a good portion of the course, I left class feeling confused and unclear of what had been accomplished in the three hours spent in the classroom. My biggest frustration was that the policy framework was presented as the only way to proceed in natural resource and no attention was given to alternative methods or viewpoints. The assigned readings for the class were often unmanageably long and not consistently discussed in class. Despite my frustrations in the classroom, I found Professor Clark to be incredibly available and helpful when talking to her in one-on-one situations, and felt that the assigned paper and presentation at the end really helped me to understand the policy sciences framework.
We were introduced to very interesting concepts/ideas and ways of approching problems, that I will definitely find helpful in my future work and studies.
Presentations by practitioners
Interactive, good speakers, great opportunity to learn the skills of problem solving

The policy sciences framework that we learned was the best part of the course. Learning it in depth and learning how to apply was really valuable. Susan was also a warm, welcoming professor and it was very helpful that she was always available and happy to meet.
There was a nice sense of community.
The subject matter taught. The student presentations.
Concepts and theory of the policy sciences; problem solving skills; goal identification; problem orientation
The instructor's engagement and enthusiasm for the concepts being taught.
Susan Clark. Guest lectures.
Professor Clark is very helpful, personable, and accessible to discuss both course material and related professional matters. She is extremely dedicated to her students and the learning process.

This was all new material to me. I did not realize what the material was about until about 3 weeks into the course, and even now I am still thinking about it, considering what bits and pieces I have learned, what I have yet to learn, what I disagree or agree with.Guest speakers were great.

The class really helped me to understand a new way of approaching problems - natural resource related or otherwise - and Professor Clark was really great about bringing in outside speakers who used the policy sciences in their work. These speakers really helped me to see how the policy sciences can be used in the real world.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I'd like for it to be less lecture/teacher oriented and more dialog/student oriented when it comes to class discussion time. That would be more in spirit of an openness that the instructor tends to promote, except when dialogs actually start. (Then student comments tend to get cut short.)
Lectures too rambling without enough content

Having the assignments listed on the syllabus, or receiving them more in advance would be helpful (a few were sent out 2 or 3 days before our next class meeting) - there was often a lot of reading and personal reflection/analysis that took a lot of time.
Clarity early in the semester. A little more organization - sometimes things seemed a bit random
The course could have had better discussion during the class time. it would have been helpful to have the class discussion centered around specific parts of the framework and how to apply it.
More examples of how the policy sciences succeeds in real life.
more discussion among students.

Instructor was not great at facilitating discussion among the group. We had a relatively quiet group of students that needed help from the instructor to open up and engage in fruitful discussion. We didn't really get there....
Maybe a field trip?

Organization of the complex concepts were somewhat lacking. Students often exhibited slight confusion as to where we were going early on in the class. The instructor was great at laying out the concepts, however, a better schedule in the beginning would benefit those not familiar with policy-based integrated frameworks.
I think this course could use more class discussion.

I view the bulk of the course material as a methodology, a set of tools to apply to problem definition and problem solving. However, the supplemental material given to provide context and support for this methodology is substantial and complex. So it would have been helpful for the professor to introduce the policy sciences as a methodology for understanding human problems from the beginning of the course.Class time was not always budgeted to provide time to discuss out of class readings. We often did not even mention the readings assigned. Perhaps in the future, at least 10 minutes might be spent just commenting on the main contributions of each article or piece we read.

I think the time spent in the classroom would be more valuable if it had more structure. As students who don't know what the policy sciences or the framework are, a more concrete, structured introduction and overview of the subject at the very beginning of the course would really help the rest of the course flow more smoothly.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The outside-class sessions with instructor were very helpful.
Susan was very generous with her time in terms of meeting with students outside of class - much appreciated!
Helpful
Susan was incredibly helpful and available outside of class time. My meetings with her were invaluable and really helped me to grasp the information and to apply it to my particular project.

Dr. Clark was readily available to talk to students, and she did take interest in our paper topics. I found it very difficult to talk to her though; it was impossible to talk/ work outside her recommended framework (the policy sciences framework), and I felt that I would be penalized for not doing so.
Good
instructor was available to talk anytime.
Great how instructor always had an open door policy and made herself available.
excellent
The instructor was readily available.
Susan is very available and always willing to talk.
By far the best experience with accessibility in a professor in graduate school thus far

I was not aware that the class had a TA, until we began receiving emails from Kanchan, at which point I thought Kanchan might be a designated student to email the class and post material on classes v2.The professor was always open, patient and very helpful and accessible to students. This was very encouraging and appreciated!

Professor Clark was always very available to talk and help. I really appreciated that the door to her office was always open, and that she was willing to sit down and spend time talking to me about course material.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: The skill is applical to people wroking on the ground and in management
This course gave me a great foundation in a particular approach to policy analysis.
This course provided a really unique and specialized way to approach any environmental issue and this was really interesting to be exposed to.

Excellent, this class not only gave me inter-disciplinary problem solving skills, but essential theories and concepts for analyzing policy and developing recommendations for improving policy. The most valuable class I will take at Yale.
As a first year MESc student, the concepts discussed in this course truly helped me approach some of the problems I encountered while developing my research project idea.
Interested in conservation, as well as building leadership and problem-solving skills.
Course is a really good intro into the philosophy and basic process behind policy and decision making
I am very happy I took this course. I think I am a more complete individual because of it.

This course provided a good starting point for understanding a way to problem solve and create effective policies. I am very interested understanding how we can make environmental policies that have a bigger impact and how people can be involved in the process to achieve that impact. This course focused a lot on the way decisions are made and how policies can fall apart when those decisions are not made properly.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was hoping it would provide one manner of thinking wholistically about problems.
This course was highly recommended to me by 2nd year MEM students and students who know/have worked with Susan.
Interest in the skills acieved through the policy sciences
I took this course because it seemed like a great foundation course for learning how to analyze policy and to approach a complicated conservation problem.

It was recommended by several people (though also strongly discouraged by several people). I was intrigued because after the first class I was still really confused as to what it was, but it seemed potentially important.
Interest
I have always had a great interest in interdisciplinary studies. I wanted to integrate the concepts into my project.
It was recommended to me by several former students.
I had heard great things about it from my class mates.
I took this course to gain a better understanding of how we can make environmental policies that are more effective.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes! I will carry lessons from this class along with me for a long time.
I did not really have expectations going into this class

This course lived up to some of my expectations. Writing the paper helped to fulfill my expectations of learning how to apply the policy sciences framework however the class discussion did not live up to my expectations.
No.
I try to never have expectations.
somewhat
More yes than no.
Yes
I was initially confused as to how the class would fit into my program, however, it ultimately exceeded my expectations. This was largely due to the instructor's enthusiastic guidance of the class.
Yes. I'd say it exceeded my expectations.
yes

I do feel like I have a better understanding of how the policy process can be used to create more effective environmental policies. I do wish that the class had also looked at other processes and also how the framework can really be applied.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I did not really have expectations for this class
No.
No expectations. It was interesting, and I think I got something out of it, but I couldn't quite tell you what, and I'm not sure it was a whole class's worth of stuff to have gotten out of it.
somewhat
Yes.
Yes
Yes.
I had no idea what to expect, so it's hard to say.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you feel you are in need to organizing your thoughts or approach to certain conservation-related environmental problems, then consider this class.
Start the final paper early.
Keep up with the readings - follow the guidlines for presentation and submissions

This course teaches you a very specific approach to policy analysis. The policy sciences framework focuses a lot on human perspectives and values and uses these to evaluate how a policy works and what is going wrong in a complicated conservation problem. The course material may not become totally clear until about halfway through the semester when students being their presentations, so don't expect to have a good grasp on the framework in the beginning and don't be afraid of all the new vocabulary. It certainly takes time to learn and chances are you won't have a firm grasp on it even after the course is over. Start the final paper early! And go talk with Susan during her office hours -- she is an incredibly valuable resource and she is really helpful in talking through your particular case and helping you to apply the framework to it. Also, keep up with your journals weekly, it will help a lot in the end! Lastly, do the readings and try to contribute to the class discussions - it makes them much more pleasant and more interesting with everyone's contribution.
I would advise them to not take this course.
Be open-minded.
Don't be afraid to challenge the philosophies of the instructor.

Do the reading, it helps in providing grounding and background. Depending on your skills, focus on the reading during the first part of the course, and then focus on your paper in the second part. Do your journals in a timely fashion. Visit the professor during office hours for help on your paper in the beginning, middle and end!
Do not be afraid of approaching the instructor. Take advantage of her availability, as it is quite unique in the grad school environment.
Keep going over introductory material. It will pay off in the long run.
Come with an open mind, and actively seek out the professor and fellow students to discuss material, especially outside of class.

Pick a topic for your final presentation and project at the beginning of the course, and each week apply what has been read and discussed to that topic. I found that I only really understood the policy process framework when I applied it to a process I had been involved in. Applying the framework to a topic from the beginning will help you to understand the process better and give you a leg up on getting your project done.
